questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia with halothane. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Suxamethonium (Succinylcholine): This drug is a depolarizing muscle relaxant commonly used in anesthesia. It can lead to a life-threatening condition known as malignant hyperthermia (MH) when used in combination with halothaneanesthesia. MH is characterized by hyperthermia, muscle rigidity, and metabolic acidosis. It results from an abnormal calcium release in muscle cells, and suxamethonium is one of the primary triggers.

Incorrect Answer Explanation:

  • (A) D-curare: Curare is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, but it does not cause malignant hyperthermia. It is less likely to cause muscle rigidity and hyperthermia in the presence of halothane.
  • (C) Cisatracurium: This is also a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, and like other non-depolarizing agents, it does not trigger malignant hyperthermia.
  • (D) Rocuronium: Another non-depolarizing muscle relaxant, rocuronium does not cause malignant hyperthermia. Non-depolarizing agents do not lead to the hyperthermic crisis seen with suxamethonium.

Key Takeaway:
Suxamethonium (Succinylcholine), when used with halothane, can trigger malignant hyperthermia, which is characterized by hyperthermia and muscle rigidity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the Endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
End tidal CO2 concentration: The best method to confirm the correct placement of an endotracheal (ET) tube is by monitoring end-tidal CO2 (ETCO2). When the ET tube is correctly placed in the trachea, carbon dioxide from exhalation is detected. A positive reading of ETCO2 indicates that the tube is in the correct position in the trachea (not the esophagus), as the lungs participate in gas exchange. This is the most reliable and quick method.

Incorrect Answer Explanation:

  • (A) X-ray of chest: While an X-ray can confirm the position of the ET tube, it is not the most immediate or practical method in the operating room. It also involves exposure to radiation, and it is typically used as a confirmatory measure after initial assessment.
  • (B) Auscultation: Auscultation of breath sounds can help identify whether the ET tube is in the trachea or esophagus, but it is not the most reliable method, as it can be difficult to distinguish sounds if the tube is misplaced or if there is asymmetric lung ventilation.
  • (D) Chest rise: While observing chest rise can suggest the tube is in the trachea, it is not a definitive method for confirming placement. End tidal CO2 is more accurate and reliable for confirming correct placement.

Key Takeaway:
The most accurate and reliable way to confirm endotracheal tube placement is by monitoring end-tidal CO2. This ensures the tube is correctly placed in the trachea, allowing for proper ventilation.

questions.text: A anaesthetist was doing shoulder block with 0.25% bupivacaine, the patient became unresponsive and pulse became unrecordable. The best management in this patient would be
questions.solution:
Local anesthesia systemic toxicity can be treated with 20% intralipid emulsion along with CPR if the patient becomes unconscious.

Cardiotoxicity and CNS toxicity are seen in the toxicity of local anesthetics like bupivacaine and levobupivacaine.

Intralipid decreases cardiac bupivacaine concentration by 11% within 3 minutes of administration and cerebral bupivacaine content by 18% within 15 minutes of administration.

CPR with 20% intralipid emulsion: Local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which includes symptoms like cardiotoxicity (unresponsiveness, unrecordable pulse) and CNS toxicity, can occur with drugs like bupivacaine. The best management in such cases is CPR combined with the administration of 20% intralipid emulsion. Intralipid acts by binding to the local anesthetic, decreasing its concentration in both the heart and brain, and helps to reverse the toxic effects. Studies have shown that intralipid can reduce cardiac bupivacaine concentration by 11% within 3 minutes and cerebral content by 18% within 15 minutes, making it an essential part of the treatment.

Incorrect Answer Explanation:

  • (B) CPR with sodium bicarbonate: While sodium bicarbonate may be used to treat metabolic acidosis or other conditions, it is not the primary treatment for local anesthetic toxicity. It does not address the cause of the toxicity or reduce the concentration of the anesthetic.
  • (C) CPR with dobutamine: Dobutamine is a sympathomimetic drug that may increase cardiac output and improve heart function. However, it does not treat local anesthetic toxicity or reduce the anesthetic's concentration in the body.
  • (D) CPR with calcium: Calcium is typically used in cases of hyperkalemia or calcium channel blocker toxicity, but it does not treat the underlying issue of local anesthetic toxicity in this case.

Key Takeaway:
In cases of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), especially with drugs like bupivacaine, the best management involves CPR along with the immediate administration of 20% intralipid emulsion, which helps reduce the toxic effects on both the heart and brain.
